The great house is visible in the pages of Lady Anne
Cliffords diary. It is It is stuffed with
furniture it is She is above all things possessive
She is aware from her first youth of her
rights, of her position She is has her [fields?]
[graved?] upon her lands. She has no
She has no doubt whatsoever tha a
profound & [fervent?] belief in the rights as the possessor.
It Even as Solid She believes, with a
in the solidity of the land; in the
rights of ownership The reality of the body is
The body is visible to her. She sma is for ever
beholding castles; acquiring land, asserting her
rights to property; accumulating; hoarding
claiming diamond buttons, making inventories of her
possessions, establishing her family, sending for her
grand children so that m they too may
taste the delights of possession. She No
The living body is robed in black taffeta with a
yellow taffeta wan [breast?].
When the body is
dead, it is wrapped in lead; to as if those were
from decay
it were to preserve it as long as possible. The
sense of the body permeates her pages: the
solidity of matter; the as if silver, diamonds,
fur cloaks esp enforced some were a
the body gained in dignity, were more was the
human soul were was more expressive, more itself
when it's carcass fleshed. to in to the public eye
the body is She reveals the emptiness of
England, when, surely to see an old countess buried
the common people come flocking. l The
effort of moving across All movements
become spectacular. Six bay horses drag the
coach. The coach is lined with green cloth &
laced with green & black silk lace; crowds
as if to solidify
them still further
attend her. And she is for ever asserting her self, her
property, with [critical?] carved in stone, even over
farm house walls. This is her property; this land
is hers. Her sense of the rights of blood, of something
sacred in flesh & blood: so when Lord Sheffield marries
Anne Erwin it "was held a very mean
match, an indiscreet on part of him." already
For the noble families, the Herberts, the Russells, the Stanleys
are already weaving themselves together; & there at
set apart weaving their webs, at the centre of which is
King James
er whole effort is to count, to amass, to hoard; & to
as if she had no sense of change; as if she believed that
it is not only right but [advisaber?] to that the concrete
body, it can survive survive; as if there were for her
an immortality of the body:
one must
proclaim its
solidity under
just
believe in the
body, as one
believes in the
soul.
Yet there were moments when hear
carapace of possessions proved to much to be any for her: when
she upon the 1st [score?] by times in the morning
& went up to the Pagan Tower to say prayers & saw
the sun rise, again she saw a strange comet like a
canopy in the sky
If I had not excellent Chaucer book here to comfort me,
I were in a pitiable case, having so many troubles
as I have here, but when I read in that, I scorn &
make light of them all, & a little part of his
beauteous spirit infuses itself in me"
It is a queer transition a strange reversal – for the
world of rubies & diamonds, from the solid
earth to the of Westmoreland, to the other world; &
a [feverish?] one, when her eye turns from the
delight of possessing land, to the other delight of the
a change of [public?] office, & these abide in
Knole, & she adds that postcript to a letter about

a little cabinet a cup 
            
              wh.
              which
             she had left with
Lady Kent, when she borrowed a hundred pounds off her
But
It is only when she reads that she comments: when she goes to
the play she says only "Supped with my Lord & Lady
Arundel & after supper I saw the play of the Mad Lover in
the Hall.. or "We stood to see the Masque in the
box with my Lady Ruthven." For the reader was born
The reader [is here?]
presumably when the playhouse
shut. The curious faculty of making [houses?] &
countries visible, men & women & their emotions, from
marks on a printed page, was in abey undeveloped
so long as the play was dominant. The
The reader then comes into existence some time in the 16th

century, & his life history, could we dis cover it, 
            
              wd
              would
be well worth writing. At some point his ear must
have lost its acuteness, at another his eye must have
lost its sharpness. Our our attempts when we read the
early plays, to supply the trumpets & the plays, the
citizens & the apprentices in an attempt [offer?] to revert to an
earlier stage. The difficulty is great. The In
trying to see read see we are trying to be among the audience:
to be a spectator not a reader. B But The We are
making an effort to forget As time goes on,
the reader Our reading faculty disturbs us;
distracts us.
But as the
As
Later, as the
reading faculty develops, readers separate into
different classes:
the
Yet the prevalence of the reader is felt even when
the re in the audience on the Bankside. It was for
him that Nashe wrote that strange amorphous book
the Poor Traveller– which which belongs to no
class, which has its the in for him that
Burton composed that extraordinary medley, the
Anatomy of Melancholy. It is through the
influence of the reader It is there that the reader
makes his first appearance; It is for it is there that
we find the writer, completely anxious of the
reader; adding here in [illeg.] & bringing
himself, the man behind the book, into existence.
He find ex [existence?] that curious power which
is as [towards?] to become highly developed – the
power af I am a sib batchelor... I am neither
rich nor poor... I am content... I am [lazy?]...
I despise book se [water?]... I am very
a tumbler over of other mens bookes... I am
a spectator, not an actor. He is There is
no audience forcing him to embody his
meditations in real people, acting a story.
And so
the vast accumulations that have littered from books
down into the great [college?] room flow meander
over the page. He cannot write a sentence without
remembering what some other man has said. But
instead of His vision is multiple. He sees
with the eyes of a thousand men; yet about
He uses the eyes of a thousand dead men to
verify what he sees. Yet He does not Yet all
these reflections serve to enrich his own vision.
Man is melancholy, now But he has been
Man has been melancholy always; in Greece in Rome;
he has been mad always; he has been cruel; he
has tortured & killed; & even in England
yet there is a tolerance in his soliloquy: he is
He sees through a thousand green shades what lies
immediately before him – the unhappy heart of
man. Yet these innumerable instances of
passion, of melancholy, the reflections serve to
chequer the immediate spectacle. There is
a From books he has won the tolerance,
mediations, the sense that we are not single
figures, but so innumerably repeated; the
individual comes He In pursuit of melancholy he
travels over the whole world, though he has never
left his college room. [portraits?] are drawn
from all [illeg.]. They are illustrated by
anecdotes
And then
For th Yet though the theme is Melancholy, the
treatment is humorous. Over the We are at a
remove from the thing treated. We are evading it
generally. We are engaging the spectacle of
melancholy, not sharing in its anguish.
That is the present gift of the book –
There we develop the other gif faculties that
the play left dormant: to [sense?], to
speculate, to the private faculties: the
the
to gloss, to [treat?], to compare, to feel our
eyes upon the writer, & to find at the
find at the centre of the labyrinth of words, a man
sitting alone in his college room, thinking – about
Now the reader is aware of completely in being
He can read in many different moods. He can
satisfy the desire for information, he can
draw in from the printed page knowledge of times past:
[illeg.] anecdotes; reflections; he can see England
at the moment: he can forge circle forwards &
backwards; he can draw in what feeds
reflections; or he can read directly what is on the page;
or drawing aside can read what is not said there.
The reader then
A sense of sense of
a sen
long drawn
Time seems endless. There is a continuity in the
book that the play has not. It gives a
different pace to the mind. It loosens it
from the present moment. We are in a
world where nothing is concluded. And
